January 25, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
In response to your request that
I summarize, from my point of
view, the reasons for and against
the adoption of the four-year rule
by the athletic authorities of the
Johns Hopkins University, I submit the following; I do so, of
course, as an opponent of its adoption, believing that it would work
a serious injustice to our athletics
and might greatly impede our
progress.
The reasons for the adoption of
the rule appear to me to be purely
Prima facie and to be swept away
by a knowledge of the facts.
Following are the principal
reasons against the adoption of the
four-year rule:
I. The Johns Hopkins University
should have teams which fairly
represent the University.
2. The University has five hundred and sixty-five graduate and
medical students .and one hundred
ahd eighty2one undergraduates (including- specials).
3. These grads and meds. have,
in nearly every instance, already
Spent four years, or more, in college.
4. The four-year rule originated
at undergraduate colleges, where
the full course is four years. It
Was never designed to bar bona
fide students from games, but
Solely to prevent athletes from
staying in college for athletic purPoses after four years.
5. To apply it to a university,
seventy-five per cent, of whose students have already spent four
Years, or more, in college, would
tend to work a serious injustice.

Mr. Benedict's Letter.

Decidedly the most important
event of the past week, was the
discovery in the Nation of a letter
signed "Bertram Benedict" and
headed "An Undergraduate View."
How it ever got in the Nation is
a mystery, but let us remember that
a couple of years ago John Kendrick Bangs solemnly declared that
if the doctor told him he only had
a week to live, he would spend it
in bed reading the Nation. "At
the end of a week of this," he concluded,"death would be a blessing."
With as much of the letter as
we understand (and we have read
.it three times!) we decidedly disagree. We believe that you are
wrong when you say that "few undergraduates of the higher intellectual types become teachers."
Look at the professors and instruciors here—at the crop of gold
keys which are dangled from watch
charms—and you will see where
you are mistaken. Run over the
Hopkins list and then look up the
records and see how many men,
who have become teachers, stood at

Interesting Debates at Last Two Meetings — Arrangements for Arbitration Meeting Under Way.

The last two meetings of the
Arbitration-Literary Society, held
the past Thursday and the week before in the Donovan Room, have
been unusually sucessful. At the
meeting on January 18 the vital
problem of the four-year rule was
hotly debated. If the sentiment of
the members of the Society shows
which way the wind blows, student
sentiment appears to be violently
against the adoption of the rule.
The meeting last Thursday was
taken up with a debate on the succulent subject: "Is Dancing Proper?" which was particiapted in by
one of our embryo divines on the
one side, and by one of our aspiring dandies on the other. The sense
of the meeting seemed to be that
the divine had the best of the argument.
At the meeting last Thursday,
President Uhler read a letter from
the Zelosophic Society of the University of Pennsylvania offering
terms for a debate, which are, in
brief, as follows:(I) That the debate shall be held in Philadelphia;
(2) That it shall take place some
time shortly after April 5;(3) That
the subject shall be some aspect of
the "Recall;" and, (4) That the
Arbitration Society be given the
choice of sides. The Society voted
to accept the terms.
Arrangements for an arbitration
meeting to be held in the near
future are also under way. A committee consisting of Messrs. Dickinson and Wolman was appointed
to arrange the details. It is expected that several papers will be
read by members at the meeting,
and that one or two speeches will
be made on the subject of International Arbitration.
Several candidates have already
announced that they will enter the
competition for the medal offered
by the Society for the best essay
written by a freshman on some aspect of the peace question. The
Society has decided to call this
medal the "Marburg Medal," in
'honor of Mr. Theodore Marburg
of this city who has done so much
for the cause of arbitration.

January 25, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
In response to your request that
I summarize, from my point of
view, the reasons for and against
the adoption of the four-year rule
by the athletic authorities of the
Johns Hopkins University, I submit the following; I do so, of
course, as an opponent of its adoption, believing that it would work
a serious injustice to our athletics
and might greatly impede our
progress.
The reasons for the adoption of
the rule appear to me to be purely
Prima facie and to be swept away
by a knowledge of the facts.
Following are the principal
reasons against the adoption of the
four-year rule:
I. The Johns Hopkins University
should have teams which fairly
represent the University.
2. The University has five hundred and sixty-five graduate and
medical students .and one hundred
ahd eighty2one undergraduates (including- specials).
3. These grads and meds. have,
in nearly every instance, already
Spent four years, or more, in college.
4. The four-year rule originated
at undergraduate colleges, where
the full course is four years. It
Was never designed to bar bona
fide students from games, but
Solely to prevent athletes from
staying in college for athletic purPoses after four years.
5. To apply it to a university,
seventy-five per cent, of whose students have already spent four
Years, or more, in college, would
tend to work a serious injustice.

In thc Maryland House of Delegates last week, Mr. Ogle Marbury
introduced a joint resolution to provide for the appointment of a committee by the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House
to confer with the University
trustees with a view to the establishment of a school of technology
by the State at Homewood, to be
conducted in conjunction with the
University. Speaker Trippe named
as the committee, on the part of
the House, Messrs. Marbury,Campbell, Maltbie, Taylor and Hargett.

Remsen issued a formal statement,
in which he said that the trustees
were eager to confer with the State
committee and see whether a
mutually advantageous arrangement
could not be reached.
It is proposed by the friends of
the University that the State appropriate $1,5oo,000 for the establishment of a school of technology, and
that the University give a certain
number of free scholarships to residents of the State. It is certainly
to be hoped that the friends of the
University who are urging the
proposal may be successful, and
that some basis may be arranged
for the establishment of such a
school.

Interesting Debates at Last Two Meetings — Arrangements for Arbitration Meeting Under Way.

The last two meetings of the
Arbitration-Literary Society, held
the past Thursday and the week before in the Donovan Room, have
been unusually sucessful. At the
meeting on January 18 the vital
problem of the four-year rule was
hotly debated. If the sentiment of
the members of the Society shows
which way the wind blows, student
sentiment appears to be violently
against the adoption of the rule.
The meeting last Thursday was
taken up with a debate on the succulent subject: "Is Dancing Proper?" which was particiapted in by
one of our embryo divines on the
one side, and by one of our aspiring dandies on the other. The sense
of the meeting seemed to be that
the divine had the best of the argument.
At the meeting last Thursday,
President Uhler read a letter from
the Zelosophic Society of the University of Pennsylvania offering
terms for a debate, which are, in
brief, as follows:(I) That the debate shall be held in Philadelphia;
(2) That it shall take place some
time shortly after April 5;(3) That
the subject shall be some aspect of
the "Recall;" and, (4) That the
Arbitration Society be given the
choice of sides. The Society voted
to accept the terms.
Arrangements for an arbitration
meeting to be held in the near
future are also under way. A committee consisting of Messrs. Dickinson and Wolman was appointed
to arrange the details. It is expected that several papers will be
read by members at the meeting,
and that one or two speeches will
be made on the subject of International Arbitration.
Several candidates have already
announced that they will enter the
competition for the medal offered
by the Society for the best essay
written by a freshman on some aspect of the peace question. The
Society has decided to call this
medal the "Marburg Medal," in
'honor of Mr. Theodore Marburg
of this city who has done so much
for the cause of arbitration.
